Daldinia decipiens is a species of fungus belonging to the genus Daldinia, which is a group of ascomycete fungi commonly known as carbon balls or coal fungus. The species is characterized by its dark, spherical to irregularly shaped fruiting bodies, typically ranging from 1 to 5 cm in diameter, which develop on the dead wood of various tree species.

The surface of the fruiting body is smooth and often has a shiny, varnished appearance. When cut, the interior of the fungus reveals a distinct concentric zoning pattern, with alternating layers of dark and light tissue. This internal structure is a distinctive feature that helps in the identification of D. decipiens.

The fungus reproduces sexually through the production of ascospores, which are microscopic spores formed within specialized structures called asci. These ascospores are released and dispersed by wind, helping the fungus to colonize new substrates and establish new populations.

Daldinia decipiens is known to be a saprotroph, meaning it feeds on dead or decaying organic matter, primarily the woody tissues of dead trees and branches. It plays a role in the decomposition of wood and the recycling of nutrients in forest ecosystems.

This species is widely distributed, with reports of its occurrence in various regions around the world, including Europe, North America, and Asia. It is commonly found on the decaying wood of deciduous tree species, such as oak, beech, and maple.
